Yes, shutting factories down will - relocating them, shutting them down is what really we've been doing for the last 4 to 5 years, but this recent surge has put a lot of factories basically below what we call cash cost.
Factors in the United States, factors in Europe that are frankly relying on just products.

Number one.

The business of converting petroleum products into the kinds of things you use everyday falls to thousands of mid and small-sized companies across North America, companies like the one owned by Tom Duffy.
He is president and CEO of Plastic Components, Inc. in German Town, Wisconsin, and he joins us now.
Mr. Duffy, could you start off by telling us about some of the things that your company makes.
We make injection-molded plastic parts that end up in almost every thing that an American consumer would use.
We make parts that end up in appliances, parts that end up in engines that go on lawnmowers and rider tractors and generators.
We make plastic parts that go into power-hand tools, and we make plastic parts that end up in automobiles, and Ford pickup trucks.
So safe to say there's a whole lot that we couldn't do without companies like yours?
No.

The plastics industries throughout North America is a multi-billion-dollar industry, and there are somewhere around 5,000 molders throughout North America, and we're all making parts that get used by consumers, every single day.
So how has the increase in oil prices affected your industry?
Alex, it's not much different from what's happened with the price of gallon of gasoline.
The increases are coming through in many cases on a monthly and even weekly basis, where the price of a pound of material that for many, many, many years didn't change by more than a penny or two.
A pound over the course of a year, is now going up five, 10, 15, or 20 cents a pound a month.
And we expect that this process is going to continue for the foreseeable future.
And possibly get much worse.
It's very likely get much worse.
The analogy that I would use would be - you're on a surf board out in the ocean in front of a 25-foot wave.
You have to stay ahead of that wave because if the wave catches up to you and crashes on top of you, the world can become a very uncomfortable place very quickly.
These prices have to be passed through to our customers, because if we don't, we - their - the business model is no longer sustainable.
If you look in to your crystal ball or perhaps for you, it's a ball made of plastic.
What do you see as the future for your industry?
(Soundbite of laughter)
So, Rick, I'll start with you on that.
Is there anything from your playing days that you wish perhaps you could change?
There is a significant rate of attrition right now, Alex.
In our industry, there's a lot of molders who either have not been able to pass on these price increases, or will not be able to pass on these price increases.
And in those cases, I think the rate of attrition is going to be severe, and it's going to be dramatic.
I've talked to a number of people in the industry, who have a much broader prospective on the North American market place than I do.

And it is their expectation that we could see an attrition rate of up to 30 percent of the molders in North America in the next 12 to 15 months, which will involve hundreds and hundreds of companies, and thousands and thousands of employees in that industry.
And a lot of these industries are heartland industries.

These are Wisconsin, Illinois, Iowa, Indiana, Michigan manufacturing companies that I think are going to be in severe distress over the next year, as the economic forces work at us from two different sides of the equation.

One is the decreasing demand for our products, just because the economic slowdown, and the other being the dramatic increase in the price of raw material, which is clearly the biggest cost driver in our industry.
Tom Duffy is president and CEO of Plastic Components Inc. in Germantown, Wisconsin.
Thank you, Mr. Duffy.
Thank you, Alex.
